awd_titl_txt: Hydrodynamics and Actuation of Magnetic Bacteria in Confined Geometries:Single cells to swarms
awd_abstract_narration:
In order to navigate their environment, many bacteria and other living micro-organisms swim by rotating a flagellum, a slender helix-shaped attachment connected to the cell body. Near surfaces, the wake produced by this rotating flagellum produces complex forces and torques that act on the bacterium. This gives rise to a range of movements that depend on the orientation of the cell relative to the surface, as well as its rate of rotation and physical geometry. Understanding these interactions at surfaces is important in the study of individual motile bacteria as well as in the development of technologies that can controllably manipulate large micro-organism populations in fluid environments. The proposed investigations will take advantage of the unique features of an inherently magnetic bacterial species, M. magneticum AMB-1, of the magnetotactic bacteria (MTB) group. Their natural magnetism allows them to be externally manipulated, providing a new means of probing the fluid-based forces arising near surfaces. Experiments that explore the role of cell geometry and orientation, magnetic content and flagellar thrust will underlie the development of models for the swimming behavior of MTB and associated fluid flow patterns.  MTB are also promising candidate organisms for biologically powered micro-actuation and robotics. In this vein, large scale cell assemblies permit several magnetic field-based devices such as "living liquid crystal" displays and bacterial "conveyor belts" to be developed.  The project will undertake outreach activities for several high school teachers in the form of an annual summer workshop. Through these activities, high school students will be able to create a connection between a fun, familiar device, an Xbox controller for example, and concepts in physics, environmental science, biology and engineering disciplines (e.g. magnetism, bacterial habitats, microorganisms, Archimedes principle) in the classroom and laboratory.

The realization of functional biology-based robotics at the microscopic level would introduce a paradigm shift in areas as diverse as materials manufacturing, nanotechnology and medicine. The proposed work will make major advances in this direction by investigating fundamental fluid-surface interactions of a model bacterial species (M. magneticum AMB-1) with innate magnetic properties. Together with micro-magnetic and micro-fluidics techniques, their magnetic organelles allow individual living bacteria and swarms be confined and guided  to yield quantitative measures of the hydrodynamic and magnetic forces as well as torques that are central to their dynamics. These quantitative parameters will serve as the foundation for developing models of their hydrodynamics on scales ranging from single cells to swarms. Integrating actuation and control of living organisms in low Reynolds number surroundings will serve as the basis to enable several novel biological and bio-hybrid machines that operate in a micro-fluidic environments. The in-situ management of the relative positions of individual cells through designed magnetic surface patterns provides for a novel means to explore pairwise cell-cell interactions that have led to the discovery of novel collective behavior such as rotating filamentary bacterial clusters, living liquid crystal magneto-optical modulators and momentum generating "conveyer-belt" tracks in these environments where viscous forces dominate. The flow fields generated by the propulsion of these flagellated swimmers will be managed to construct microscopically tunable pumps, mixers and hydrodynamic assemblers. The project will undertake stimulating outreach activities for high school students and teachers that link physics, environmental science, biology and engineering disciplines both in the classroom and laboratory.

Project Outcomes Report for NSF grant titled, Hydrodynamics and Actuation of Magnetic Bacteria in Confined Geometries: Single cells to swarms

Emergence of order from a collection of active components such as ant colonies and bird flocks are widespread in nature. Although the principal traits of such emergent phenomena (their spontaneity and distinctive forms) are well documented, a mechanistic understanding of these behaviors however remains limited. On the micrometer scale, our world is filled with swimming microorganisms such as bacteria, that also display emergent collective behavior. The swimming strategies at the macroscopic scale (e.g. fish or birds) are however different from much smaller microcopic species. The desirable properties of biological systems (self-replication, healing and adaptation) operating across length scales from the nanoscale to the organismal level and beyond, has motivated interest in developing alternative approaches to controlling matter that are derived from biological systems. 

This research provided a closely integrated experimental-computational study of individual as well as dense suspensions of a special type of bacteria - an inherently magnetic bacterium species, M. magneticum AMB-1. The advantage of investigating such organisms is that each bacterium carries a magnetic signature that enables for remote, investigator-control, of their orientation and movement by weak external magnetic fields. Bacterial taxis is central to understanding how these single cell organisms live in their environment and how their dynamics in a fluid operates at a range of length scales.

The propulsive thrust needed for the bacteria and similar entities to swim relies on the rotation of their flagellum, a slender helical attachment connected to their cell body. The rotating helical filaments, called flagella and powered by molecular motors, are a valuable indicator of the overall energetics of the cell. Determining the properties of this propulsive system is a crucial step to unraveling the behavior of these organisms. Near surfaces several complex forces and torques emerge, giving rise to a range of movements that depend on the orientation of the cell relative to the surface, as well as its rotational velocity and cellular geometry. These interactions at surfaces are important in the study of individual motile bacteria, their collective movements as well as in the development of technologies that can control large micro-organism populations within fluid environments.

Bacteria confined to thin patterned disks of cobalt-iron traps were used to non-invasively determine their flagellar thrust force and swimming speed enabling the ratio of propulsive force to swim speed (the hydrodynamic resistance) and the power output of the flagellar motor for individual cells to be determined. Beyond individual bacteria, self-assembly is an important emerging proces within bacterial populations. The latter is also a promising avenue toward dynamic and responsive micro- and nano-technologies - of both synthetic and biological microswimmers, The region of disturbed flow away from the moving bacteria, caused by the fluid flow around the body (similar to those produced by a traveling boat) leads to interactions with neighboring swimmers and nearby surfaces. These interactions associated amongst bacteria with magnetic signatures revealed a variety of self-assembled patterns. including static and mobile bands and two-dimensional clusters near a boundary that can be tuned with magnetic fields.

Models describing the novel geometric formations, locomotive patterns of these motorized individuals, and resulting flow fields were developed. The computational model concurrently considered the interactions due to motion of fluids and forces on the bacteria immersed in the fluid and their couplings to exterior stimuli (oxygen, gravity, and magnetic field) to reproduce all observed collective phenomena. The analyses were implemented on a parallel graphic processing unit (GPU) computing platform to establish a clear mechanistic understanding of the large-scale emergent phenomena in the bacterial system. The detailed explanations for the observations in magnetic bacterial suspensions demonstrates a viable pathway toward predicting and studying new collective behaviors in natural and synthetic systems.

Several graduate and undergraduate students were trained in bacterial hydrodynamics, fluid flow, cellular dynamics and micro-magnetic techniques. The experimental skills were complemented by developing computational models describing geometric formations, locomotive patterns of motorized microorganisms, and resulting flow fields. In addition, several high school students and a high school teacher participated in the project prior to curtailment of this outreach effort due to the Covid pandemic. The portable magnetic platform system was taken to high school classrooms and images of swimming, student-collected MTB projected onto a screen.  We believe this creates a connection between a fun, familiar device, like an Xbox controller, and "difficult" concepts in physics (e.g., magnetism, thermal motion, Archimedes' principle).
